Table 5 Image, table 5 Image, table 5 Image, table 5 An unconventional direct path for the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes over a metal-free catalyst Zongyan Ma a b Jing Chen a Ming Chen a Linkun Dong a Weiwen Mao a Yu Long a ⁎ Jiantai Ma a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University Lanzhou 730000 China aState Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, China b Hotan Normal College, Hotan 848000, China Hotan Normal College Hotan 848000 China bHotan Normal College, Hotan 848000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In recent years, significant efforts have been devoted to the fabrication of heteroatom-doped carbon materials as ecofriendly catalysts to replace metal-based catalysts employed in the hydrogenation of nitroarenes. However, the reaction pathway of metal-free catalysts has not been thoroughly studied. In this study, nitrogen-doped hollow hierarchical porous carbon materials have been successfully prepared. The porous nitrogen-doped carbon was prepared by carbonizing at 900°C (PNC-900) and exhibited an exceptional catalytic performance in the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes with high tolerance to various substrates under mild reaction conditions. The analysis of the experimental results and characterizations, revealed that graphitic N species were the primary catalytic active sites and played a crucial role in efficient hydrogenation. The reaction followed a special direct path in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene (NB) owing to the absence of nitrosobenzene (NSB) as an intermediate, which was markedly different from the other metal-free catalysts. Moreover, the PNC-900 catalyst exhibited excellent reactivity and selectivity even after six cycling tests, thus demonstrating unconventional high performance in terms of both recyclability and stability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Unconventional direct path Nitrogen-doped carbon Metal-free Graphitic N Hydrogenation of nitroarenes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Owing to the rapid industrial development, significantly large amounts of harmful organic substances have been discharged into the environment [1]. Nitroaromatic compounds, are hazardous organic pollutants with potential carcinogens and mutagens [2]. However, one of their hydrogenation products, the aromatic amine moieties, are important feedstocks for the synthesis of fine chemical products, dyes, pharmaceuticals, polymers, and bulk chemicals [3,4]. Conventionally, various metal catalysts, such as Fe [5,6], Co [7–9], Ni [10,11], Pt [12,13], Pd [14,15], Au [16,17], and Ag [18], have been widely used in the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes owing to their good performance [19–22]. However, their industrial-scale applications are significantly restricted by their limited availability, high cost, and poor stability [23]. Additionally, the leaching of metal ions from metal-based catalysts into reaction systems can contaminate the products and cause severe environmental pollution [24,25]. Therefore, the development of metal-free heterogeneous catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity and excellent stability that can be used for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes to their corresponding anilines must be urgently developed for green and sustainable chemistry. Carbon materials that are low-cost, highly efficient, environmentally friendly, and naturally abundant, were first developed and applied as a metal-free catalyst in fuel cells in 2009 [26]. Since then, carbon materials have attracted increasing attention owing to their advantageous properties, such as easy preparation procedures, large specific surface areas, adjustable porous structures, and excellent thermal and chemical stability [27,28]. Metal-free catalysts based on carbon materials have been extensively employed in the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes [29]. However, several carbon-based catalysts exhibit low catalytic activity owing to the lack of active sites. Hence, surface modifications and heteroatom doping have been utilized to enhance the catalytic activity [27,30-33]. Doping heteroatoms into a carbon structure can provide additional heteroatom-containing active species, tailors the chemical properties of the catalyst and further facilitate electron transfer during the reaction [32]. Among the various heteroatoms, nitrogen (N) atoms can be easily incorporated into different types of carbon materials, and they always act as electron donors because their radius is similar to that of carbon atoms (0.77 Å) and their electronegativity (3.04) is higher than that of carbon atoms (2.55) [34]. Various methods to fabricate N-doped carbon materials have been developed, including the hard [35] and soft template [36] methods. The hard template method generally includes multiple procedures and involves the use of corrosive and toxic reagents. By contrast, the soft template method is simple and environmentally friendly, and it yields carbon materials with high nitrogen content and abundant porosity [37]. The flower-like organic melamine-cyanuric acid (MCA) crystals exhibit significant potential as a novel soft template. During the high temperature carbonization, the framework of the MCA is well maintained, whereas its surface nitrogen is doped into the carbon skeleton [38]. Additionally, the hierarchical porous structures resulting from the decomposition of the soft template can enhance the catalytic activity; this is expected to benefit mass-transfer and provide sufficient active sites for catalysis. Hydrogen sources, such as H2 [39], HCOOH [40], NaBH4 [41], and N2H4·H2O, have been widely used in the hydrogenation of nitro compounds. Compared with other hydrogen sources, N2H4·H2O is more appealing because of its safety and generation of only harmless N2 and H2O as by-products, attracting increasing interests of scientists [21]. In our previous research, metal-free catalysts and hydrazine hydrate have been applied in the hydrogenation of nitroarenes [5,19,21,31,42]. On the basis, an in situ soft template method was rationally designed to prepare porous nitrogen-doped carbon (PNC) materials as metal-free catalysts for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes with hydrate hydrazine as an ecofriendly reductant. The catalyst we synthesized exhibited hierarchically porous structures and large specific surfaces, and was applied as an efficient non-metal catalyst for the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes. Moreover, the high specific surface area, porous structures, lattice defects, and graphitic-N species in PNC catalysts synergically contributed to the high catalytic activity, stability, and extensive substrate tolerance. Additionally, the reaction route was studied over the PNC-900 catalyst. Unlike previous reports, the hydrogenation of NB over PNC-900 followed an unconventional direct path without the formation of nitrosobenzene (NSB) as an intermediate. This research aims to demonstrate an unconventional pathway for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes with a highly efficient metal-free catalyst. 2 Experimental section The materials, characterization methods, and preparation of catalysts can be found in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of PNC catalysts The preparation procedure of the catalysts is illustrated in Scheme 1 . First, melamine and cyanuric acid (CA)were self-assembled into supramolecular aggregates via hydrogen bonding to yield rose-like MCA, which was used as both the template-growth agent and nitrogen source. Second, cyanuric chloride (CC) was covalently linked to MCA aggregates via a simple nucleophilic substitution reaction. Third, CC and piperazine were polymerized based on the substitution of the chloride atoms of CC for the imine groups of piperazine to obtain PCC@MCA precursor. Finally, PNC materials were obtained by carbonizing the PCC@MCA precursor under a N2 atmosphere at different temperatures. MCA served as a self-sacrificing template during the carbonization, and it started degrading at 300°C and completely decomposed above 600°C (Fig. S1). 3.2 Structural characterizations of precursor and PNC catalysts The Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra are presented to elucidate the chemical structures of MCA, CC, and PCC@MCA (Fig. 1 a). The absorption peaks at 3200–3400 cm−1 are characteristic of N–H and O–H groups. Evidently, all samples exhibited strong peaks corresponding to the aromatic C–N heterocycles at 1200–1700 cm−1, and the absorption band at 807 cm−1 is ascribed to the typical breathing mode of the C–N heterocycles of tris-triazine units [38]. The peak at 1299 cm−1 corresponds to the aromatic C–N stretching vibration of piperazine in PCC@MCA. The C–Cl stretching peak at 851 cm−1 in CC is not found in the spectrum of PCC@MCA, thus indicating the successful substitution of the chloride atoms of cyanuric chloride [43]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns in Fig. 1b show two characteristic peaks at approximately 25° and 43°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) planes of graphitic carbon, respectively, suggesting that the PNC materials are composed of graphitic carbon and amorphous carbon [44,45]. Raman spectroscopy was performed to further verify the effect of N-doping on carbon materials. As shown in Fig. 1c, two distinct peaks were observed at wavenumbers of around 1350 (D band) and 1580 cm−1 (G band). The D band corresponds to lattice defects that can induce active sites for catalysis applications, whereas the G band is closely related to the sp2-hybridised carbons (E2g symmetry vibration mode) [46,47]. Therefore, the relative intensity ratio of the two bands (ID/IG) can be utilized to determine the degree of the structural defects and graphitization of carbon materials. The ID/IG values of all the samples were similar (1.14, 1.08, 1.04, and 0.99 for PNC-700, PNC-800, PNC-900, and PNC-1000, respectively), indicating that the lattice defects created by the doped N decreased in the carbon framework. Additionally, the ID/IG values decreased with the carbonization temperature owing to the reduced percentage of nitrogen atoms at high temperatures (Table 1 ) [48]. N2 adsorption/desorption experiments were performed to analyze the specific surface area and pore structures of the carbonized samples. As shown in Fig. 1d, a type-Ⅰ isotherm exhibiting equilibrium in the range of P/P0 < 0.01 indicates the existence of abundant micropores [49]. Additionally, the isotherm curves of all the samples correspond to Ⅳ-type, with an H4 hysteresis loop in the middle region (0.5 < P/P0 < 0.9), suggesting the existence of mesoporous structures [50,51]. Furthermore, the sharp peaks at high relative pressures (P/P0 > 0.9) indicate the presence of abundant macropores. The corresponding pore size distributions, estimated using density functional theory (DFT) simulations (Table S1, Fig. S2), revealed that micropores and mesopores were dominant. The abovementioned results indicate that all the carbonized samples exhibit hierarchical porous structures, which make them suitable catalysts for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes. The introduction of MCA into the precursor framework has an obvious impact on the specific surface area and nitrogen contents [42]. The calculated BET specific surface areas of PNC catalysts listed in Table 1, were significantly higher than those of PCC@MCA (31.8 m2g−1) and MCA (1.7 m2g−1) (Fig. S3). This was primarily because of considerable mass-loss corresponding to the C, N and O in the precursor frameworks and the decomposition of MCA, resulting in a hollow carbon network of PNC catalysts. The aforementioned results indicate that the prepared PNC-900 material possesses a large specific surface area and hollow structure with abundant porosity, which could provide a large number of active sites, facilitate the rapid diffusion of reactants and enhance the catalytic activity [52]. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) were conducted to investigate the morphology and porous structure of the resultant materials. As shown in Fig. 2 a, MCA aggregates were composed from a pile of nanosheets, essentially forming rose-like microparticles with a mean size of 2.8 µm. The mean diameter of the particles increased to 5.7 µm after modification by CC and piperazine (Fig. 2b). After calcination at 900 °C, the rose-like morphology disappeared with the formation of a porous honeycomb-like structure owing to the release of reductive NH3 and CO2 gases from the precursor (Fig. 2c). Additionally, the particles became smaller (2.3 µm) because of the shrinkage of the skeleton at a high temperature. The TEM image (Fig. 2d) shows that the structure of PNC-900 is hollow with abundant pores. The EDS mapping images of PNC-900 (Figs. 2e and f) suggest that C and N were distributed uniformly across the sample. The surface chemical compositions and atomic bonding information were investigated via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 3 a, three peaks at 285, 398, and 531 eV are indexed to C 1s, N 1s, and O 1s, respectively [44,53]. Table 1 summarizes the detailed elemental analysis (EA) and XPS results, wherein the N contents decreased with the increasing carbonization temperature. In the high-resolution C 1s XPS spectra (Fig. S4), five peaks, C–C/C=C (284.5 eV), C=N (285.6 eV), C–N (286.6 eV), C=O (288.1 eV) and O–C=O (289.5 eV) were observed [54]. The presence of C–N and C=N peaks indicates that nitrogen atoms were successfully doped into the carbon framework, in line with the results of elemental mapping (Fig. 2f). The high-resolution spectra of N 1s for PNC samples (Fig. 3b–e) include three peaks at 398.3, 400.3, and 401.2 eV, attributed to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N, respectively [52,53,55,56]. The percentage of different nitrogen species calculated based on the peak areas are summarized in Table 1. Evidently, the nitrogen content estimated using EA was higher than that obtained via the XPS analysis for all the samples, indicating that nitrogen is evenly distributed rather than concentrated on the surface. 3.3 Evaluation of reaction conditions for the NB hydrogenation All the as-prepared PNC catalysts were evaluated as metal-free catalysts for the hydrogenation of NB to AN. As listed in Table 2 , evidently, the PNC-900 exhibited excellent conversion and selectivity, with a TOF value of 0.0250 mol g−1 h−1, which is higher than those of PNC-700, PNC-800, and PNC-1000 (Table 2, entries 1–4). The hydrogen source was changed from hydrazine hydrate to NaBH4, HCOOH, and H2 using PNC-900 as the catalyst. Hydrazine hydrate facilitated a higher conversion of NB to AN than the other hydrogen sources (Table 2, entries 5–7). Further screening of the reaction conditions revealed that the conversion considerably correlated with the polarity of the solvent (Table 2, entries 8–11). The hydrogenation of NB to AN was further investigated using H2O/EtOH mixture with different volume ratios (Table 2, entries 12–15). The lowest reaction conversion and selectivity were obtained in pure water possibly because of the poor solubility of NB and dispersibility of the catalyst in water (Table 2, entry 12). As the volume ratio of EtOH increased, the conversion of the reaction also increased (Table 2, entries 13–15). Therefore, EtOH was used as the solvent for subsequent reactions. Compared with the excellent conversion and selectivity achieved by 20 mg of the catalyst within 1 h (Table 2, entry 3), the conversions were lower when the catalyst dosages were 10 and 15 mg (Table 1, entries 16–17). Moreover, the hydrogenation of NB to AN was performed at different temperatures. A significant decrease in the conversion of NB to AN was observed at 80°C (Table 2, entry 18). Therefore, 90°C was selected as the optimal reaction temperature, rather than 100°C (Table 2, entry 19), to reduce energy consumption. 3.4 Identification of active sites and possible intermediates To illustrate the catalytic performance of the catalysts, contrast experiments were conducted. The hydrogenation of NB did not occur without the catalyst (Table 3 , entry 1) or hydrazine hydrate (Table 3, entry 2). Although the lattice defects of the as-synthesized catalysts were crucial for the hydrogenation activity, they were not the active sites in the hydrogenation procedure because PNC-700 that had the highest defect content was not the catalyst with the highest activity (Fig. 1c). The NB conversion was higher over PNC-900 than that over PNC-800, although both had similar specific surface areas, indicating that the specific surface area was not the decisive factor for the catalytic activity. Therefore, further comparative experiments were conducted, and the results are summarized in Table 3. A commercially available catalyst, namely active carbon (AC), was purified by washing in 1 mol·L−1 HCl at 50°C for 5 h and used in the reaction. However, only a very small amount of NB was converted to AN (Table 3, entry 3). Additionally, the conversion of NB was not observed when the active carbon was further oxidized by NaOCl to produce oxygen-abundant active carbon (OAC) [57] (Table 3, entry 4). Therefore, carbon and oxygen species might not be catalytic active sites for this reaction, implying that doped nitrogen played an important role during the process. As listed in Table 1, both the EA and XPS analysis results revealed that the nitrogen content decreased with increasing carbonization temperature. The highest catalytic activity was obtained over PNC-900, indicating that different species of nitrogen, rather than the total nitrogen content, were responsible for the catalytic activity. The relationship between different nitrogen species and catalytic performance was further elaborated. As presented in Fig. 3 and Table 1, the relative peak areas of graphitic N increased with temperature, probably because of its thermal stability, whereas the areas of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N peaks decreased. For PNC-1000, the pyrrolic N peak disappeared; however, it exhibited a high NB conversion (81.2 %, Table 2, entry 4), thus indicating that the pyrrolic N contributed negligibly to the catalytic activity. Considering the strongest basic site properties of pyridinic N reported by previous literatures [58], temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was performed to analyze the basic sites of PNC catalysts (Fig. S5). The CO2 desorption peaks, which were attributed to the adsorption of CO2 on basic sites of PNC catalysts, were observed at around 100°C [59,60]. As the carbonization temperature increased, the position of CO2 desorption peaks shifted to lower temperatures from 137°C to 71°C while the desorption peak areas decreased, suggesting that the interaction between CO2 and doped-N became weaker and weaker [59]. Combining with the content of nitrogen species in Table 1, it was found that the CO2 desorption peak areas were correlated strongly with the pyridinic N content. However, the CO2 desorption peak areas did not show any correlation with the catalytic activity of PNC samples. Hence, it was concluded that pyridinic N cannot account for the catalytic activity. To further validate this assumption, two comparative experiments were conducted using PNC-900 as the catalyst, in which the hydrogenation of NB were performed with or without adding 1 mL of acetic acid (HAc) [53]. If pyridinic N was predominant in the catalysis, the addition of acetic acid should neutralize the basic sites and reduce NB conversion. However, as listed in Table 3, entry 5, the conversion of NB was not affected by acetic acid. The above analysis suggests that graphitic N played a crucial role in the catalysis of NB to AN. The relationship between the NB conversion and the relative content of graphitic N was explored. As expected, the conversion of NB was directly proportional to the relative graphitic N content (Fig. 3f). Based on the aforementioned analysis, we speculated that graphitic N was the active sites for catalysis, which was in line with previous reports [31,53,61]. The decomposition of N2H4 could generate hydrogen species with three electronic states [62]: (1) H atom (H δ0), which might form hydrogen gas and escape from the reaction system; (2) H radical (H·), which might react with butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) as a radical scavenger; and (3) polar Hδ+ and Hδ−. The catalyst exhibited no activity when H2 was used as the reducing agent (Table 2, entry 7), indicating no H atoms were formed during the decomposition of N2H4. Further, the hydrogenation conversion was not influenced by the addition of BHT to the reaction system, suggesting that the decomposition of N2H4 could not generate H radicals. Hence, the hydrogenation of NB to AN occurred in the presence of Hδ+ and Hδ−. The two pathways generally accepted in the hydrogenation of NB are the “direct pathway” and the “condensation pathway”, in which NSB and PHA are essential intermediates, as proposed by Haber et al. in 1898 [63] (Scheme. 2 a), On the contrary, Jackson et al. [64] proposed a new mechanism without NSB intermediate with the Pd/C catalyst. Our group has previously reported nonexistence of NSB as an intermediate in the entire reaction process when hydrazine hydrate is used as reductant [5,19]. Based on the theory that our group already has, we systematically studied the reaction pathway for the hydrogenation of NB with metal-free catalysts, which, to the best of our knowledge, has not been previously explored. Most of the studies have reported the reaction way based solely on the substances detected in the reaction system [44,65]. Owing to the thermal decomposition of PHA detected via GC, the hydrogenation of NB was monitored as a function of time via high performance liquid chromatogram (HPLC). As shown in Fig. 4 a, the existence of PHA and AOB were both detected in the reaction system. The accumulation of PHA decreased gradually with the reaction time, whereas the percentage of AOB was very low through the entire hydrogenation process. Additionally, NSB was not detected at any stage of the reaction process. Contrast experiments were conducted to analyze the intermediates in hydrogenation of NB (Table 4 ). PHA, AB, AOB, and NSB could be hydrogenated to AN with different yields under the identical reaction conditions. The yield of aniline reached 65.9 % when PHA was used instead of NB as the substrate (Table 4, entry 1). However, the yields of aniline were relatively lower than that of PHA when AB and AOB were used as substrates (Table 4, entries 2–5). When NSB was used as substrate, it could be completely hydrogenated to AN, even without the addition of catalyst, let alone the addition of catalyst (Table 4, entries 6–7). If NSB was an intermediate, the same product should be formed as that obtained from NB. The difference between the hydrogenation of NB and NSB led us to presume that NSB may not be an intermediate. To further confirm this assumption, contrast experiments were conducted. To reduce the rapid hydrogenation of the intermediate by excess hydrazine hydrate, the amount of hydrazine hydrate was reduced to 1 equivalent of the substrate. The yield of AN obtained from the hydrogenation of NB was only 2.8 % when the dosage of hydrazine hydrate was decreased to 30 µL (1 equiv. related to NB), without any byproduct (Table 4, entry 9). Completely different from the result of NB hydrogenation, the yield of NSB hydrogenation to AN with an equivalent hydrazine hydrate was 88.9 % (Table 4, entry 8). To further elaborate the difference between NB and NSB hydrogenation, equal NB and NSB quantities were added into the system at the beginning of the reaction (Table 4, entry 10), and the yield of aniline reached up to 30.7 % accompanied by byproducts AB (2.6 %) and AOB (16.9 %). The obvious increscent of AN yield could be attributed to the hydrogenation of NSB. Moreover, AOB could be detected five minutes later in the system when equal amounts of NSB and PHA were simultaneously added to the catalysis system, and the yield of AN was 10.1 % after 1 h (Table 4, entry 11). Hence, we ruled out NSB as an intermediate in the hydrogenation of NB with hydrazine hydrate, which was different from previous reports. We concluded that NB was converted to PHA directly, and then further hydronated to AN (Scheme. 2b). In the case of the undesired AOB and AB generated from self-condensation of PHA, PNC-900 could hydrogenate them to the target product AN. Based on the aforementioned experimental results and analysis, the hydrogenation of NB over PNC-900 was achieved through PHA intermediate without the formation of NSB as an intermediate. 3.5 A proposed reaction mechanism A reasonable mechanism for NB hydrogenation was proposed on the basis of the experimental and theoretical analyses. The graphitic N atom was located at the center of the surface, whereas the others were located at the edges [61]. As illustrated in Scheme. 3 , graphitic N has stronger electronegativity than the C atoms adjacent to it. One hydrogen atom of N2H4 preferentially combined with graphitic N, whereas the nitrogen atom of N2H4 combined with the positive carbon atom adjacent to the graphitic N. During the reversible adsorption and desorption processes of NB on the surface of the catalyst, the N–H bond in the N2H4 was broken, thereby generating electropositive N–Hδ+ species, electronegative C–Hδ− species and N2H2. N2H2 further underwent the same catalytic cycle and formed N2, N–Hδ+, and C–Hδ−. The hydrogenation of NB to AN proceeded with N–Hδ+ and C–Hδ−. Finally, the desorption of AN from the catalyst indicated the completion of the entire catalytic cycle. 3.6 Recyclability and stability of PNC-900 in hydrogenation of NB A limitation of metal catalysts in the industrial applications is the deactivation caused by the loss of metal active components. However, the N-doped carbon materials obtained via high-temperature calcination were expected to have a more stable structure than those metal catalysts. After the completion of one reaction, the PNC-900 catalyst was washed with EtOH several times via centrifugation and dried for the successive reuses. The conversion and selectivity remained almost unchanged even after six cycles (Fig. 4b), suggesting the excellent recyclability stability of PNC-900, which demonstrates promising prospects for future practical applications. 3.7 Kinetic study over PNC-900 The concentration of hydrazine hydrate was far higher than NB and could be considered as constant. The linear fit between the reaction time and the concentration of NB and AN (Fig. 5 a) suggests that the hydrogenation of NB followed pseudo-zero-order kinetics, differing from metal-based catalysts that generally follow pseudo-first-order kinetics [66,67]. A series of experiments were carried out to further elaborate the dynamics over PNC-900. Linear fits between the concentrations of AN and reaction time were obviously observed, with increasing slopes of the lines with incremental dosage of catalysts (Fig. 5b). Additionally, the slopes of the line were constant while the initial concentrations of NB were different (Fig. 5c). Thus, it could be concluded that NB adsorption/desorption on the surface of the catalyst reached equilibrium quickly. However, only NB adsorbed on graphitic nitrogen can be activated; therefore, the real concentration of NB in the catalytic system was determined by the amount of graphitic-N, rather than by the concentration of NB in the solution [53,68,69]. Subsequently, the NB was hydrogenated to AN by hydrogen species (Hδ+ and Hδ−) in steps. The reaction kinetics over PNC-900 were further conducted at 70°C, 80°C and 90°C to analyze the catalytic performance and apparent activation energy (Ea) (Fig. 5d). The reaction rate constant κ was estimated to be 0.001250, 0.00091, and 0.00067 mmol·L−1·min−1 for 70°C, 80°C, and 90°C, respectively. The Ea calculated according to the Arrhenius equation (κ = Aе−Ea/RT) for the hydrogenation of NB over PNC-900 was 32.2 kJ·mol−1, as shown in Fig. 5e. This calculated Ea value is lower than those of previously reported metal-based catalysts or other metal-free catalysts [53,69-71], further confirming the outstanding performance of the PNC-900 catalyst. 3.8 Hydrogenation of various aromatic nitro-compounds over PNC-900 The catalytic activity of PNC-900 in the hydrogenation of other nitroarenes containing electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups were examined under optimal reaction conditions. The results listed in Table 5 indicate that the activity was affected by the electrical property of the substituted groups in the nitroarene substrate. Notably, the hydrogenation of electron-donating methyl, methoxy, and nitrile-substituted nitrobenzene exhibited good to excellent yields over an extended time (1.5–8 h) (Table 5, entries 1–5). For meta- and para- methyl nitrobenzene, higher conversions were obtained than those for ortho-methyl nitrobenzene (Table 5, entries 2 and 3 vs 1), possibly owing to the steric hindrance effect [44]. Importantly, the selective hydrogenation of the nitro group to the corresponding amino group was observed in the presence of the nitrile and nitro group (Table 5, entries 5, 17). Moreover, halogen–substituted nitroarenes were hydrogenated with higher conversions and selectivity in a relatively short time without the dehalogenation products (Table 5, entries 6–16), suggesting that PNC-900 was superior to other reported N-doped catalysts [72,73]. However, the nitrobenzene with a fluor-group exhibited slight dehalogenation, which might be owing to the strong electronegativity of the fluorine group (Table 5, entries 6–7). Nitro compounds with CC and CC substituents as highly reducible functionalities showed inferior selectivity toward corresponding amines (Table 5, entries 18–19), accompanied by distinctly reduced products. 4 Conclusion In summary, nitrogen-doped carbon materials with hollow hierarchical porous structures were successfully synthesized by carbonizing a nitrogen-abundant precursor. Subsequently, these ecofriendly metal-free catalysts were applied for the chemoselective hydrogenation of different nitroarenes and demonstrated significant catalytic performance. Their large specific surface area, abundant porosity, evenly-doped N in the carbon framework, and lattice defects caused by N-doping synergistically contributed to enhance the catalytic activity. The reaction followed an unconventional direct way owing to the accumulation of PHA as intermediate but without the formation of NSB. Detailed analysis of the experimental results and related characterizations revealed that graphitic N species were the major active sites in the hydrogenation process. Notably, owing to the high structural stability and recyclability of PNC-900, no distinct decrease in the conversion and selectivity was observed even after six cycles of NB hydrogenation. This study offers new pathways for the rational design and development of heteroatom-doped carbon nanostructures as metal-free catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, significant efforts have been devoted to the fabrication of heteroatom-doped carbon materials as ecofriendly catalysts to replace metal-based catalysts employed in the hydrogenation of nitroarenes. However, the reaction pathway of metal-free catalysts has not been thoroughly studied. In this study, nitrogen-doped hollow hierarchical porous carbon materials have been successfully prepared. The porous nitrogen-doped carbon was prepared by carbonizing at 900°C (PNC-900) and exhibited an exceptional catalytic performance in the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes with high tolerance to various substrates under mild reaction conditions. The analysis of the experimental results and characterizations, revealed that graphitic N species were the primary catalytic active sites and played a crucial role in efficient hydrogenation. The reaction followed a special direct path in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene (NB) owing to the absence of nitrosobenzene (NSB) as an intermediate, which was markedly different from the other metal-free catalysts. Moreover, the PNC-900 catalyst exhibited excellent reactivity and selectivity even after six cycling tests, thus demonstrating unconventional high performance in terms of both recyclability and stability.
coredata.dc:title: An unconventional direct path for the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes over a metal-free catalyst
